Article: Productivity

You're a Computer Athlete

You're likely a professional computer user â€“ you should behave like the athlete that you are

entry.content:
Article: Tana

Data About Nodes - Fields and Tags in Tana

entry.title: New Time Units for Higher Productivity (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Productivity

New Time Units for Higher Productivity

Our common measures of time never worked for me for time management. So I invented my own.

entry.title: The Input Channel Audit (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Attention Design

The Input Channel Audit

A quick How To guide for shaping your information diet

entry.title: Develop Strong Criteria for Input Triage (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Attention Design

Develop Strong Criteria for Input Triage

'How in the world. You need less Twitter in your life.' I had, again, discarded my guard rails of attention design and failed at input triage.

entry.title: The Seven Questions At The Heart Of Knowledge Ops (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Knowledge Ops

The Seven Questions At The Heart Of Knowledge Ops

Personal Knowledge Management is too restrictive â€“ you want to think about all seven of these questions instead.

entry.title: The Grazing â€“ Feeding Model of Information Gathering (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Knowledge Ops

The Grazing â€“ Feeding Model of Information Gathering

On the Internet, information is limitless. The Grazing-Feeding Model of Information Gathering helps you know how you're engaging with that information.

entry.title: Sadly, Constraints Are Real (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Constraints

Sadly, Constraints Are Real

For the last 15 years I've ignored one fundamental truth: real constraints exist. Here's what I'm trying now.

entry.title: Adversarial Reading (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Algorithm of Thought

Adversarial Reading

Bullshit is everywhere, and these algorithms of thought help you do more adversarial reading.

entry.title: How to improve a process (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Productivity

How to improve a process

With taking notes as an example, let's talk about how to improve any process.

entry.title: Don't Fiddle With Your Note-Taking System (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Note-taking

Don't Fiddle With Your Note-Taking System

You should stick to one note-taking system and fiddle with it as little as possible. That's a myth.

entry.title: Get Rid of Peer Review and Academic Journals (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Peer Review

Get Rid of Peer Review and Academic Journals

Why to get rid of peer review and academic journals as we know them â€“ and possibly what to do instead.

entry.title: You Actually Need to Context Switch (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Atomic Essay: Productivity

You Actually Need to Context Switch

Common wisdom says that you need to avoid context switching. That's only half true â€“ sometimes you need to context switch.

entry.title: How to Context Switch Like a Pro (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Productivity

How to Context Switch Like a Pro

Context switching is unavoidable â€“ but you can make it less costly by combining a couple of simple strategies.

entry.title: A Tale of Two Biases: How To Read The News (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

A Tale of Two Biases: How To Read The News

Counter two frequent biases while reading the news: Selection Bias and Description Bias.

entry.title: How to use Roam Research for Interstitial Journaling (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Interstitial Journaling

How to use Roam Research for Interstitial Journaling

Interstitial Journaling is a great technique for minimizing context switching costs and staying productive. Here's how I use it in Roam Reserch.

entry.title: Why You Should Pick Zotero As A Reference Manager (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Academic Workflow

Why You Should Pick Zotero As A Reference Manager

A guide to reference managers, what you should expect from them and why Zotero is the reference manager you should use - whether you're in academia or not.

entry.title: Behavior First, Theory Second (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Learning

Behavior First, Theory Second

Behavior and Theory are two heuristics that can help you in deciding between courses and teachers.

entry.title: True Algorithms of Thought Have Arrived (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Algorithm of Thought

True Algorithms of Thought Have Arrived

Can you imagine being able to transfer 'mental software' between people? It's now possible, by using Algorithms of Thought in Roam Research.

entry.title: The Power of Keystone Habits with Roam Research (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Programming Attention

The Power of Keystone Habits with Roam Research

How to use Roam Research as your keystone habit to regularly revisit writing that is important to you, using the âˆ† feature in Roam.

entry.title: Zotero and Roam Research (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:

Zotero and Roam Research

A guide for using Roam Research together with Zotero to get the most out of your citation metadata.

entry.title: A short (preliminary) guide to Spaced Repetition in Roam Research (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:

A short (preliminary) guide to Spaced Repetition in Roam Research

entry.title: My grandfather's research technique - Index, Proto-Zettelkasten, Paper (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Zettelkasten

My grandfather's research technique - Index, Proto-Zettelkasten, Paper

My grandfather's way of doing history research before the computer age. Using paper and a meticulous process, he built something close to a Zettelkasten.

entry.title: How to cure Highlight Dementia (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

How to cure Highlight Dementia

How to make sure that you never lose insights when reading and highlighting. Because Highlight Dementia is completely preventable.

entry.title: Actor's Concepts and Inventing Discovery (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

Actor's Concepts and Inventing Discovery

How discovery became an actor's concept - and what you can use that for. Can you play chess without knowing that you are doing so?

entry.title: Getting Started with Algorithms of Thought (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Reading

Getting Started with Algorithms of Thought

An introduction to Algorithms of Thought - how they differ from Mental Models and how to use them in Roam Research.

entry.title: Universal-X - Of Polymaths and other fantastic creatures (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Polymathy

Universal-X - Of Polymaths and other fantastic creatures

There are words you can't use to describe yourself without sounding like an utter ass. Imagine asking someone at a party who they are and they respond with 'Nice to meet you, I'm a brilliant photographer/physicist/writer' - instant, life-long friends you'll be, no?

entry.title: The Right to Disagree (Cortex Futura)
entry.content:
Article: Algorithm of Thought

The Right to Disagree

Contrary to popular belief, you can't just disagree with someone because you feel like it. You have to __earn__ the right to disagree with someone's position.

entry.title: Continent-wide declines in shallow reef life over a decade of ocean warming (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Continent-wide declines in shallow reef life over a decade of ocean warming

A systematic census at 1,636 sites around Australia from 2008 to 2021 finds that more than 30% of shallow invertebrate species in cool latitudes exhibit a high extinction risk due to declining populations and oceanic barriers, but tropical coral species remain relatively stable.

  • Graham J. Edgar
  • Rick D. Stuart-Smith
  • Amanda E. Bates
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: RHOJ controls EMT-associated resistance to chemotherapy (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
RHOJ controls EMT-associated resistance to chemotherapy

RHOJ regulates epithelial-to-mesenchymal-transition-associated resistance to chemotherapy by enhancing the response to replicative stress and activating the DNA damage response, enabling tumour cells to rapidly repair DNA lesions induced by chemotherapy.

  • Maud Debaugnies
  • Sara RodrÃ­guez-Acebes
  • CÃ©dric Blanpain
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Dense reinforcement learning for safety validation of autonomous vehicles (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Dense reinforcement learning for safety validation of autonomous vehicles

An intelligent environment has been developed for testing the safety performance of autonomous vehicles and its effectiveness has been demonstrated for highway and urban test tracks in an augmented-reality environment.

  • Shuo Feng
  • Haowei Sun
  • Henry X. Liu
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Acceleration of 1I/â€˜Oumuamua from radiolytically produced H2 in H2O ice (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Acceleration of 1I/â€˜Oumuamua from radiolytically produced H2 in H2O ice

Acceleration of â€˜Oumuamua is due to the release of entrapped molecular hydrogen formed through energetic processing of an H2O-rich icy body, supporting the idea that it originated as a planetesimal relic similar to Solar System comets.

  • Jennifer B. Bergner
  • Darryl Z. Seligman
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Structural basis of mitochondrial membrane bending by the Iâ€“IIâ€“III2â€“IV2 supercomplex (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Structural basis of mitochondrial membrane bending by the Iâ€“IIâ€“III2â€“IV2 supercomplex

A supercomplex comprising all four respiratory chain components contributes to the induction of mitochondrial membrane curvature and tubulation of cristae.

  • Alexander MÃ¼hleip
  • Rasmus Kock Flygaard
  • Alexey Amunts
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Beating the break-even point with a discrete-variable-encoded logical qubit (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Beating the break-even point with a discrete-variable-encoded logical qubit

The lifetime of a qubit in a circuit quantum electrodynamics architecture can exceed the break-even point through quantum error correction, representing a key step towards scalable quantum computing.

  • Zhongchu Ni
  • Sai Li
  • Dapeng Yu
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Gut enterochromaffin cells drive visceral pain and anxiety (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Gut enterochromaffin cells drive visceral pain and anxiety

Visceral pain and anxiety in mice are found to be associated with gut enterochromaffin cells, and genetic models for eliciting visceral hypersensitivity and studying the sex bias of gut pain are proposed.

  • James R. Bayrer
  • Joel Castro
  • David Julius
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: From primordial clocks to circadian oscillators (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
From primordial clocks to circadian oscillators

X-ray, cryo-EM and kinetic studies of the circadian oscillator KaiBC from the photosynthetic bacterium Rhodobacter sphaeroides shed light on the evolution of self-regulating oscillators.

  • Warintra Pitsawong
  • Ricardo A. P. PÃ¡dua
  • Dorothee Kern
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Interhemispheric competition during sleep (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Interhemispheric competition during sleep

Electrophysiological recordings in sleeping bearded dragons (Pogona vitticeps) reveal a type of interhemispheric competition that is detected in the claustrum but generated in the midbrain, and only during rapid-eye-movement sleep.

  • Lorenz A. Fenk
  • Juan Luis Riquelme
  • Gilles Laurent
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Photosynthesis re-wired on the pico-second timescale (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Photosynthesis re-wired on the pico-second timescale

By using in vivo ultrafast TA spectroscopy, extraction of electrons directly from photoexcited PSI and PSII in cyanobacterial cells using exogenous electron mediators is demonstrated.

  • Tomi K. Baikie
  • Laura T. Wey
  • Jenny Z. Zhang
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Real-time quantum error correction beyond break-even (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Real-time quantum error correction beyond break-even

A study demonstrates the extension of a lifetime of a quantum memory using active quantum error correction and reinforcement learning.

  • V. V. Sivak
  • A. Eickbusch
  • M. H. Devoret
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Population dynamics of head-direction neurons during drift and reorientation (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Population dynamics of head-direction neurons during drift and reorientation

Mice maintain the memory of previous associations between head direction neurons and allocentric cues and this influences the internal head direction representation.

  • Zaki Ajabi
  • Alexandra T. Keinath
  • Mark P. Brandon
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: A helium-burning white dwarf binary as a supersoft X-ray source (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
A helium-burning white dwarf binary as a supersoft X-ray source

Analysis of a supersoft X-ray source shows an accretion disk whose optical spectrum is completely dominated by helium, suggesting that it is a white dwarf binary accreting helium from a hydrogen-free donor star.

  • J. Greiner
  • C. Maitra
  • R. Vanderspek
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Thalamus drives vocal onsets in the zebra finch courtship song (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Thalamus drives vocal onsets in the zebra finch courtship song

In songbird, thalamus drives a small population of premotor neurons to initiate transitions between song syllables.

  • Felix W. Moll
  • Devorah Kranz
  • Michael A. Long
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: RBFOX2 modulates a metastatic signature of alternative splicing in pancreatic cancer (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
RBFOX2 modulates a metastatic signature of alternative splicing in pancreatic cancer

Analysis of messenger RNA splicing in a large cohort of pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma tumours identifies differential splicing correlating with disease progression, associated with the the splicing regulator RBFOX2.

  • Amina Jbara
  • Kuan-Ting Lin
  • Rotem Karni
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Quantum-enabled millimetre wave to optical transduction using neutral atoms (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Quantum-enabled millimetre wave to optical transduction using neutral atoms

We report an ensemble of cold 85Rb atoms strongly coupled to a superconducting resonator and optical cavity, resulting in the demonstration of quantum-enabled transduction of millimetre wave photons to optical photons.

  • Aishwarya Kumar
  • Aziza Suleymanzade
  • Jonathan Simon
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: 2D fin field-effect transistors integrated with epitaxial high-k gate oxide (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
2D fin field-effect transistors integrated with epitaxial high-k gate oxide

The epitaxial synthesis of high-density, vertically aligned arrays of two-dimensional (2D) fin-oxide heterostructures is described, enabling the fabrication of 2D fin field-effect transistors with high electron mobility and desirable low-power specifications.

  • Congwei Tan
  • Mengshi Yu
  • Hailin Peng
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Structural and mechanistic insights into fungal Î²-1,3-glucan synthase FKS1 (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Structural and mechanistic insights into fungal Î²-1,3-glucan synthase FKS1

Using cryo-electron microscopy, the molecular architecture and catalytic mechanism of action of the fungal Î²-1,3-glucan synthase FKS1 are determined.

  • Xinlin Hu
  • Ping Yang
  • Hongjun Yu
Article 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Quantum-well states at the surface of a heavy-fermion superconductor (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Quantum-well states at the surface of a heavy-fermion superconductor

By using millikelvin scanning tunnelling microscopy to study atomically flat terraces on U-terminated surfaces of the heavy-fermion superconductor URu2Si2, the two-dimensional heavy fermions are shown to form quantum-well states on the surface.

  • Edwin Herrera
  • Isabel GuillamÃ³n
  • Hermann Suderow
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023

entry.title: Ultrafast structural changes direct the first molecular events of vision (Nature - research articles)
entry.content:
Ultrafast structural changes direct the first molecular events of vision

One picosecond after photoactivation, isomerized retinal pulls away from half of its numerous interactions with its binding pocket, and the excess of the photon energy is released through an anisotropic protein breathing motion in the direction of the extracellular space.

  • Thomas Gruhl
  • Tobias Weinert
  • Valerie Panneels
Article Open Access 22 Mar 2023
